definition: sensationalism/vulgar claptrap to please the crowds/playing to the gallery/demagogy
clamor/noise/(bound form) sound used to call cats
crashing sound
variant of 嘩|哗[hua2]
abbr. for 眾議院|众议院[Zhong4 yi4 yuan4], House of Representatives
many/numerous/crowd/multitude
variant of 眾|众[zhong4]
to take/to get/to choose/to fetch
to love/to pamper/to spoil/to favor

sentences.english: The Indian health ministry has described the report as "sensational".
sentences.chinese: 印度卫生部称这一报道是哗众取宠。

sentences.english: That TV show is nothing but titillation . It's got no substance.
sentences.chinese: 那个电视节目只会哗众取宠，没有任何内容可言。

sentences.english: He took great pains to write on his subject without a trace of sensationalism.
sentences.chinese: 他尽力不带一丝哗众取宠的色彩来写作他的题材。

sentences.english: Don't use a silly, grandiose user ID or screen name.
sentences.chinese: 不要使用愚蠢的，哗众取宠的ID或昵称。
这仅仅是一个“哗众取宠”的帖子。

sentences.english: This curry favour by claptrap attitude, nothing but is wants to attract the attention of others.
sentences.chinese: 这种哗众取宠的心态，无非就是想引起他人的注意嘛。

sentences.english: Many politicians like to make waves in order to be kept in the media.
sentences.chinese: 许多政客能在媒体上路脸儿而不惜哗众取宠。

sentences.english: Most of the politician's speech was a load of clap-trap.
sentences.chinese: 大多数政客的演说不乏哗众取宠的空话。

sentences.english: Predictably, much of that time was instead spent grandstanding.
sentences.chinese: 不难预测，大部分时间都被浪费在哗众取宠上了。

sentences.english: Many politicians like to make wxdyes in order to be kept in the media.
sentences.chinese: 许多政客为了能在媒体上路脸儿而不惜哗众取宠。

definition: to angle for fame (idiom)/to fish for compliments
to show off (loanword, from English "show")/to grandstand/to perform in a stage show
to make a show of being original or unconventional (idiom)
vulgar/poor taste
deliberately mystifying/to make sth unnecessarily complicated
to pick up what others say (idiom); to pass off other people's opinions as one's own/to parrot
bad habit/evil custom/vulgarity
empty words/bogus speech
to fool the world and usurp a good name (idiom)
to sing the high part/to speak fine sounding but empty words (idiom)
"sensational headline writers", people who write misleading titles in order to generate clicks from Internet users/clickbait
to obscure the facts (idiom); to mislead the public with prevarication and deliberate falsehoods
amusing speech or act/jokes/antics/funny/amusing/Taiwan pr. [xue1 tou2]
to quote out of context (idiom)
to moan about imaginary illness/fussing like a hypochondriac/fig. sentimental nonsense
to put on an act
